title: Bill Gebhardt - Replicating Discretionary Commodity Trading Systematically (S7E9)

rawLines.text: okay Bill are you ready I am ready all
right three two one Let's
Jam hello and welcome everyone I'm Cory
hoffstein and this is flirting with
models the podcast that pulls back the
curtain to discover the human factor
behind the quantitative
[Music]
strategy Cory hoffstein is the
co-founder and chief investment officer
of new found research due to Industry
regulations he will not discuss any of
new found research's funds on this
podcast all opinions expressed by
podcast participants are solely their
own opinion and do not reflect the
opinion of new found research this
podcast is for informational purposes
only and should not be relied upon as a
basis for investment decisions clients
of Newfound research May maintain
positions and securities discussed in
this podcast for more information visit
think newf found.com
[Music]
in this episode I speak with Bill gibart
founder of 10 Dynamics Bill spent the
better part of his career as a
discretion AR energies Trader with roles
at Koch Industries Merl Lynch Deutsche
Bank and trailstone in May 2020 he
struck out on his own to co-found 10
Dynamics given Bill's fundamental and
discretionary background it may come as
a surprise that 10 Dynamics runs a fully
systematic process this dichotomy serves
as the foundation for much of our
conversation where Bill provides insight
into where and how his discretionary
background informs the systematic
process both from a signal and a
riskmanagement perspective we discuss
the types of signals 10 Dynamics
incorporates into their process how
their risk management system is designed
to reflect Bill's experience managing
discretionary Traders and how they've
designed their operational risk
management to allow them to trade
intraday with a small team please enjoy
my conversation with Bill
[Music]
gibart Bill welcome to the podcast
excited to have you here coming at a
very popular Trend following strategy
very popular in the last couple of years
but from a completely unique
discretionary Trader angle so I think
this is going to bring an interesting
new light to what I think most listeners
would say is a well trodden topic
hopefully I think we're going to get
some exciting new stuff here so thank
you for joining me really appreciate you
being here thanks Corey great to be here
so I disclosed a little bit about your
background but maybe you can tell us a
little bit about how you got into the
industry your background as a
discretionary energies Trader and how
you ultimately decided to make the
switch to running 10 Dynamics as a fully
systematic shop sure well if I start I
guess as far back as my undergrad I was
a chemical engineering major in
undergrad and my last year or coming up
to last year of my degree I needed to
get a part-time job and I got a job at a
brokerage stock brokerage to help one of
the Brokers just do sort of the I guess
clerking type stuff that they needed
back then and my first day on the job
was October 19th 1987 so I literally
started on the day of the stock market
crash which was interesting because I
wasn't as emotional about it as
everybody else was because I wasn't
really that familiar with Finance but it
was such an amazing event I think that
happened and it really got me intrigued
in finance and when I looked to graduate
as a chemical engineer and looked at
what chemical Engineers did compared to
what Finance people were doing it just
seemed like well that was a lot more fun
so so I switched my interest in finance
and ended up getting a master's degree
in finance and then worked in Chicago on
the CBOE as a clerk for Floor Trader the
options exchange which again was a
fantastic experience and for those who
are younger you'll never get the chance
to be in an open outcry pit which I
think is one of the really unique and
instructive experiences of my life in
terms of watching how complete chaos can
turn into order which is that's what the
floor was all about so did that for a
few years and ended up eventually going
back to get a PhD in finance because I
felt like I needed a bit more education
and did my PhD at Cornell when I
finished that and debated about going
into Academia I ended up getting hired
at an energy Trading Company worked for
Coke energy and that business evolved
ended up doing a joint venture with the
utility called ENT Coke and from there
that got acquired by bank got acquired
by maril Lynch and spent most of my
career doing energy trading and managing
prop trading desk and prop Traders
primarily all in Europe so I've ended up
in Europe with a joint venture with
enery Coke in about 2001 and and pretty
much stayed my whole career in Europe
their energy and I think probably most
Commodities in general are very
fundamentally based in their approach so
they tend to have fundamental models
forecasting demand Supply and and
discretionary trading off the back of
those models and and so initially I got
into to kind of the fundamental
forecasting side of things and
eventually ended up managing a trading
desk covering a lot of energy products
in Europe and did that at a couple banks
eventually and then we basically spun
out of a bank and started a private
Equity funded energy Trading Company in
about 2013 and I was one of the the
original Partners there and built an
energy trading business with a large
team of prop discretionary Traders and
and that was really my focus for quite a
few years and over that time though I
had because of my PhD and quantitative
background I developed some tools that I
used for my own trading and actually
shared with some of the people on the
desk a bit to to try to give indications
of when fundamental type ideas might or
might not be right timing and people
talk a lot about that about using price
signals for timing with fundamental
signals and and I've been improving and
working on those models for quite a
while and eventually we ended up hiring
a systematic team at my last company and
it was really interesting because they
were very successful and they were
successful in ways that I hadn't seen
anyone else be successful in the past in
terms of being pure systematic in energy
because I thought given how the
relationships are very Dynamic and
things are always changing that it would
be difficult to do but actually it was
definitely possible and achievable and
when the business that I was in decided
to kind of shift gears in their focus
and I was wondering what I was going to
do I decided to basically leave and see
if I could use the tools that I built
over my career and put them in to a
full-blown system and apply them to a
much wider range of markets than I could
follow as a discretionary Trader and and
that's what I did so that started about
just when covid started was when we
started the company and we've been kind
of going ever since and now we're three
years in on live track record and things
have been going pretty well well there's
a lot to unpack there and again as I
said at the intro the idea of having
someone who's come from such a strong
fundamental perspective to translate
that into a fully systematic perspective
I think there's going to be a lot of
interesting crossovers but one of the
things I want to start with is actually
on the risk side because in our preall
you mentioned to me that the vast
majority of the disasters that you've
seen in your career have largely related
to optimization or maybe over
optimization I wanted to start this
conversation maybe with some examples
that you could provide of those cases
and how that has ultimately informed
some of your ear thly designed decisions
at 10 Dynamics again moving into this
fully systematic process yeah I mean we
can go all the way back to when I was a
PhD student so I was a PhD student kind
of in the middle of my time there at
Cornell and that's when you had the
long-term capital disaster and that was
obviously as you can imagine was a big
deal in Academia because there were some
pretty high-profile academics involved
in that problem and optimization at the
end of the day relies on sort of a
belief in stable statistical
relationships right you have to have
something stable to be optimizing
towards otherwise you're not really
achieving anything and you had long-term
Capital Management was getting famous
because they were sort of proving the
counterargument to efficient markets and
then all of a sudden Not only was it not
an Arbitrage they were capturing that
was brought down the entire Financial
system so it was used by a lot of I
guess market efficiency type people as
an example of how the markets truly are
efficient but it was a good example to
be skeptical about what looks like
potentially stable relationships and
markets that can end up being highly
unstable and and from there when I moved
over to energy one of the things you
learn again in Commodities and
definitely in energy is that things can
be quite unstable relationships unstable
particularly correlations the
correlation is one of the things that I
became very skeptical of just because in
commodity markets you get substitution
effects so you can have a small change
in prices that will cross a substitution
boundary and basically your correlation
can go from high to zero in a moment and
so because of that you look at what
people in those markets use they are
almost all fundamental models where they
use switching models basically to regime
switch between different substitution
effects rather than using kind of
statistical correlation based models you
know that sort of fit with my I guess
belief that correlations were risky to
rely on amongst other relationships and
then when I was at one of the banks I
worked for pre 2008 they had lots of
businesses that were these kind of
correlation driven highly optimized
models that were up to that point
working very successfully and and then
2008 happened and a lot of those things
that were Hedges based on the
correlation turned out to be leverage
bets at the end of the day and you saw
things that were either minor or major
blowups along the way and and that just
again reinforced my concerns over
optimization and I just started to feel
like well
what's better assuming that you know
something or assuming you don't know
anything where's your base what's your
basian prior if you don't know anything
it's sort of well e everything and so
that's kind of how I arve the approach
that we take is that we to bias the
model in any one way or another we have
to be really certain that we have a
handle on things being stable otherwise
you sort of tilt things in one way and
then next thing you know you have an
event come along it ends up switching
everything around so those were some of
the things that over time colored My
Views a bit cont to some of the leading
Trends in the systematic space today
when you were starting to build out your
program you didn't really want to let
the computer figure out what works by
just looking at the data you wanted to
sort of replicate what you would do as a
Trader and I think that's a very
interesting and novel approach and again
relies on your background of being a
discretionary Trader but I find it
interesting that It ultimately seemed to
boil down into what is effectively a
trend following approach curious why do
you think that was the case I think it
actually was the case for me and maybe
for people like me in the sense that I
tend to be a visual learner so I've
always liked graphs and charts and stuff
and when you get exposed to this
industry and you see a graph the first
thing you see is some massive trend on
some's chart where it moves for years
and you think gosh you know if you only
catch one or two of those you can make a
career out of that and so I think it was
really looking at charts and seeing
these long trends that really come off
long dated time frames and again that
naive I guess we're all naive at some
point when you start something and
coming in from from an engineering
background I used to look at those
charts without knowing anything about
random walks or anything like that and
thinking gez how hard can it be to
predict this stuff it's got to be pretty
straightforward so I sort of decided to
crack the code or try to crack the code
and how to capture those B big trends
and you can contrast that with I've been
kind of fortunate in my career to work
with some very good traders who had a
very different approach and they were I
would call them numeric in their views
and they would never look at charts not
even really interested in charts but
very numbers based and so for people who
are numbers based what you tend to do is
you see a number and you think that
number is high or low based on some
whatever Intuition or fundamental model
or whatever and so people who are
numeric what you see from them is they
gravitate a lot towards mean reverting
or fundamental strategies and they can
be very successful doing that too so I
think for me it's not that Trend falling
is better or worse than anything else It
just fits my mental model I think when I
look at how I learn versus that very
price B see I'm the opposite I look at
prices and it doesn't say anything to me
whether it's high or low I don't know
how to assess whether price is high or
low I always thought well if it's low it
can keep going lower so I ended up
pursuing basically models that would try
to that type of behavior can you talk a
little bit about the frequencies at
which your Trend models trade and how
you came to choose those
frequencies it's a little bit what I
just spoke about I was really focused on
these
long-term structural shifts where
markets would double or triple over time
and then reverse and go back down and so
I was naturally attracted to long-term
time frames and really then it became a
question of well how long is too slow
and you get to time frames where you're
Trading for your future generations and
so I stopped focused mostly on weekly
and slightly longer time frames never
really did anything with monthly time
frames and then it becomes a question of
okay well how quick can you be if you're
going to start with a long-term time
frame work your way slower how fast can
you go and one thing that's definitely
true the market Behavior does change as
much as we like to think that our
philosophy is the market behavior is the
same on all frequencies once you get
below a certain frequency Market
Behavior changes quite a bit jumps
become a lot more important you get mean
reversion it becomes a lot more of an
influence and trading costs go up and so
there is a point at which I think Trend
falling really doesn't work or even make
sense anymore and for us we went down
and we kind of stopped at about a 30
minute time frame it's about as low as
we go in our analysis and then from
there we're looking at how many time
frames make sense to trade within that
bracket and you can kind of divide it up
and eventually if you divide it too
small you end up with very little
between each one of the time frames so
across that different slices we sort of
worked out that like 10 to 15 different
time frames make sense and and that's
where we focused our analysis in our
preall you mentioned that when you look
at contribution analysis the returns
that you have generated largely come
from the long-term Trend positioning but
that a lot of the risk management in the
program comes from the short-term
positioning and Readjustment from those
short-term Trends how do you think about
this interplay and how do you think
about balancing these signals to strike
the right mix between return opportunity
versus risk management if you look at
the return for any unit of Risk by time
frame what we see in our model is the
longer the time frames the higher the
return on risk so even when you
normalize on the risk of that time frame
the higher time frames are more
successful and more trendy I guess you'd
say than the shorter term time frames
and so that would make you think well
then we should just focus really on the
longterm time frames and if you do that
you can see that if you sort of bucket
the signals by time frame then yeah for
sure you get the highest returns per
unit risk out on the longer term time
frames but the unique thing I guess
about the shorter term time frames is
that let's say you look at a maybe
something on a weekly basis and it's
been trending for a while if you zoom in
on it obviously you'll see counter Trend
moves and those counter Trend moves can
look very big on shorter term time
frames so if you have a model that can
capture those shorter term Trends what
it effectively does if you just think
about two time frames you have a
long-term time frame and a short-term
time frame is that short-term time frame
Hedges the long-term time frame right
when it's in a draw down so even if the
expected return on that short-term
signal is low as long as it cuts the
draw down on the long-term signal so it
might the short-term signal will
effectively absorb the loss and then as
it comes back even if the net return on
that that signal is zero but still will
have reduced your draw on long-term
signal you get this nice balance of the
return you know your capturing these
structural movements in the longer term
charts but at the same time you're
controlling your draw Downs using the
short-term trends that occur within
every move basically as you increase
that speed typically transaction costs
become a larger percentage of the total
return as well how do you think about
that tradeoff again with the idea of
those short-term signals can be very
beneficial from the risk management
perspective but they may be ultimately
costlier to execute and therefore a
further drag on performance yeah I mean
that's definitely true and we have a
pretty good price impact model that you
know uses spreads and Vol adjusted
spreads and stuff to account for that
and as I mentioned the risk adjusted
Returns on those short-term time frames
does decline as you get quicker and
quicker so really just Bec comes a
question of well at what point does the
Hedge benefit gets outweighed by the
trading cost and that fits into kind of
where we stop with our analysis at that
sort of 30 to 60 Minute time frame and
there's a point at which it becomes
marginal and then there's a point at
which it becomes detrimental and so
that's kind of The Guiding I guess
principle that we used in terms of how
fast we want the model to be because we
think we just can't capture or maybe
there aren't even capturable Trends on
those shorter term time frames it's more
of a me reverting game anyway so I think
it's important to know or be able to
estimate what those trading costs are
and look at your net performance on each
time frame and as long as it's
contributory you know then it's probably
going to provide a decent hedge benefit
for the overall model one of the unique
features you mentioned in our preall was
that your models try to incorporate the
amount of time it takes a market to
perform a certain action sort of as this
means of I think the phrase you used was
capturing whether psychology has shifted
I was hoping you could talk a little a
little bit about why this is an
important feature for you to include and
maybe how you think about including it
mechanically but particularly through
that lens of your background as a
discretionary Trader when you look just
purely at the time aspect of a given
Trend and it's it's almost a topology
but if you look at an uptrend and you
count every day that the market was
going up and then you count every day
the market was going down you have more
up days and down days in an uptrend and
vice versa and a downtrend that's sort
of regardless of the size of each one of
those steps so it's kind of the two
steps forward one step back and that
that is one way of looking at how prices
move but it also fits well you can say
is it any different than looking at
price and it is because for everyone
who's been in the market you've
experienced these events and we've had
one recently where you might have a very
sudden Trend reversal so Market's been
trending in a particular direction and
you have this sudden Trend reversal and
then usually comes out of the blue from
some sort of shock that was unexpected
or drives if you're short it drives some
kind of short covering rally because
it's something that comes out of
people's expectations so if you look at
the behavior of those events well how
are you going to grade that behavior
they can be really fast so the momentum
can be real high so it's going to say
well maybe psychology shift because the
speed is increased in the opposite
direction of the trend a lot of times we
look at how linear movement is like does
it go in a particular direction steadily
every day or is it kind of back and
forth back and forth so those shocks
tend to be very linear as well so again
it looks like it's a potential
psychology change in May if you're a
traditional kind of breakout Trader
oftentimes they break key levels and
they can be bigger than the previous
move that was preceding him and then you
see that event and then you think okay
Everything's changed and next thing you
know well it gets reversed steadily over
time and you're back into the original
Trend if you think of recent examples
covid is a primary example of this
October 87 was another one where you
just had this incredible move down and
then you slowly reversed up from there
the only way we can identify that it
really hasn't changed the psychology is
to say well actually what it did it
happened in a very short period of time
people haven't had time to adjust to
this different mindset or maybe it's
just a shock and then people are going
to go back to thinking what they were
thinking before and so it is it's like
an independent measure that may line up
with what price is doing may not and it
definitely has value and time times when
it's saying something different than
what your kind of price behaviors
signals might say anyone who runs a
trend following program ultimately runs
into the choice of whether they want
their signals to be truncated in any way
so you can sort of run these continuous
signals or it's very common for people
to run binary signals and you mentioned
that you run binary signals rather than
that more continuous distribution and I
think the quote you used in our preall
was that you didn't want to be fooled by
false ision and my push back to that
might be binary signals on the other
hand would be incredibly imprecise when
Trends are weak right when you have very
little Trend signal all of a sudden
you're getting a big plus one or a big
minus one indicating a stronger Trend
than really exists how do you balance
the robustness versus accuracy tradeoff
when you think about measuring Trends
well I mean we think about like why did
we prefer the binary signals in the
first place and there are a lot of
signals this lines up with some Equity
fundamental signals some other signals
that I think people are probably
familiar with that if you bucket your
signal into desiles and then you look at
kind of the expected return for the
given desiles what you see is almost an
s-shaped pattern a lot of signals have
this almost mean reverting quality at
the extremes so you can have the 10th
desile having lower Returns on the
upside than say the the seventh desile
so at the times if you're going to use a
distribution type signal actually when
it's the strongest it's not nearly as
strong as you think so it's not even
that it's not accurate it's actually has
potential to predict the other way so
and then if you break it down you take
that same signal and you break it down
into quartiles what you find is actually
there's really no statistical difference
between the two quartiles so then you're
stuck with kind of a binary signal
anyway so yeah you end up kind of
working your way back into a binary
signal and saying well this is the most
bus but you're right they're subject to
flip-flopping back and forth right if
you're close to whatever the boundary is
that you're using to create the signal
so that's why we use several different
signals and combine them so we have 10
Dynamics is the company name because we
have 10 signals that we combine and we
add those up so for any given binary
it's true it can flip around a lot but
when you start adding lots of binaries
together and then you add across
different time frames what you actually
end up back with is a distribution but
that distri ution if you look at that is
much more predictive in terms of the top
desiles and the bottom desiles being
more significant than the middle and
than the center and so you turn signals
that have these sort of s-shaped
predictive characteristics into
something that that does actually have
the ability to forecast at the extremes
so I want to switch from talking about
the signal side of the equation to the
risk management side which is just as
potentially even more important in any
sort of systematic or discretionary
trading program and again in our preall
you mentioned that you wanted to design
your risk system to mimic some of your
experience in managing discretionary
prop Traders just hoping you could
expand on that a bit maybe talk about
how you think about risk budgets both at
the portfolio level and the position
level yeah I mean one of the really
important things I think for a lot of
discretionary Traders is being and
knowing the difference between when you
have a goodidea and when you don't and a
good discretionary Trader when they have
something that they really know is an
edge and they are able to fully deploy
their Capital that's sort of the
definition of being a good discretionary
Trader when those events happen you
should make a lot of money but what you
see the difference between the really
great discretionary Traders and the ones
that aren't as good is that what happens
in the interim periods when you actually
don't have a great Edge and you don't
have a lot of information that you think
is something that is different from what
the crowd thinks and you find is forr
questionary Traders because they tend to
like to trade it's hard for them to not
trade in the same sort of size and
deploy the same amount of risk even when
they're kind of sure versus when they're
totally certain so what will happen is
those Traders will have an event where
they had the right View and they make a
lot of money and then they spend the
rest of the year whatever it is trading
sort of lukewarm types of ideas with a
lot of risk and they end up giving back
and having a big draw down and and
losing a significant portion what they
made I have seen in the past a few
notable examples of traders who would
come in and literally not make a trade
for weeks or even months and then
they'll get an event or they'll have
some information that they think gives
them an edge and they'll trade their
full risk and they'll make their year
and in a short period of time and then
that's all they do and that's a thing
that translates I guess a little bit
into systems and where I guess the ideal
discretionary Trader would have zero
risk most of the time and then 100% risk
the rest of the time for us what we do
is we try to allow the system even at
the asset level to scale within fixed
risk budget what that means for us is
that we'll have an equal risk budget for
every asset that we trade we're
basically equalizing the risk across the
different assets and then within that
you'll have a position based on we call
it the model confidence it's effectively
how strong the signal is and we run at
about 40% of Max position either long or
short on average obviously that can be
up to 100% deployment on that particular
asset and it can be zero so that's at
the asset level what that means though
because again we don't really Flex the
portfolio risk up and down it's just
this equal distribution of risk across
the assets it means the portfolio itself
has quite significant risk scaling that
happens naturally just from the signals
so we run at about 40% of our Max risk
40 45% of our Max risk on average we can
be as low as 20% on the portfolio so we
can be quite lowly deployed and that's
when we look at all the assets we trade
and the model is just not really
strongly positioned in any asset and
then you can have times where a lot of
things are trending and our deployment
will be quite high and and we'll have a
lot of risk deployed relative to the
average we can look at because I know
other funds do this well they don't like
idle risk right so they want to force
the model to be fully deployed so if we
scale up when the model has a low
deployment relative to its risk budget
we can scale scale it up and scale it
down we find is that hurts returns
because it effectively means you're
putting more Capital At Risk when your
model is forecasting less strong
movements and you don't increase your
risk when the model is forecasting High
movements so by equalizing everything
you kind of hurt the performance both in
terms of the return and in terms of the
draw down control so I don't know how
many other systematic people do it that
way but we definitely think it's
something that contributes to the return
anyone who has
designed a systematic strategy that uses
an ensemble as signals will be well
aware of the core problem that even when
these signals are positively correlated
it's unlikely just statistically that
they're all going to point in the same
direction at the same time which can
often mean you're never using your full
risk budget that you might allocate to a
particular instrument curious how you
tackle this problem well it's kind of
what we just spoke about we'd call it a
feature rather than a problem you're
right it's difficult for the model On
Any Given asset to be 100% deployed when
you look at how often each asset is at
100% deployment within its risk budget
it's probably less than 10% of the time
I'd say and if you when you look at the
portfolio as a whole we reach Max risk
maybe once or twice a year so the risk
scaling that we get it does seem to
because the returns are so much higher
at the moment you're deploying most risk
it does seem to make up for that effect
of the fact that you're under deployed
when the risk is low so yeah we actually
think the fact that you're not always
100% convinced and that kind of stuff
that that's really a feature of the
model in our preall you mentioned that
in your back testing if you looked at
independent 5-year periods since 1990
there would have been very little alpha
decay in your program and this is a
pretty significant departure from what
we see in more traditional Trend
followers who cany have seen their Alpha
arguably Decay every 5 years since the
1990s particularly struggling in the
2010s fingers crossed the 2020s are
better but why do you think this is the
case is it something unique about the
markets that you're trading maybe a
little bit more of a focus on European
energy markets is it the frequency and
types of signals you're using or maybe
something about the way you manage risk
to be clear like when you talk about the
2010 tens we don't see and I guess we're
maybe a little bit unique you know we
use the same model for everything and we
don't change the parameters over time or
change it across the cross-section so we
can look back and what we do see is a
very strong cyclicality in Alpha across
the entire portfolio so you do have time
periods and it's not just like one year
is high and the next year is low you
have three or four years in a row where
really Al is really strong and then you
have three or four or five years in a
row where it's really weak in the 2010s
you know even for us I would say our
sharp ratio was about 70% of what we
consider our average expected sharp
ratio but if you look at the period

new deal p&l that's the pnl you would

specifically with the trades you just
did in that day so it's how your

you did on that day and you look at okay

good principle to start with the second
thing is
we decided not to go for kind of a

harder it's conceptually harder it's

we run the entire system front to back
runs every 30 minutes across all the
assets that we trade almost as it from

kind of the principles we started with
and then the concept that my partner
came up with was this idea of the
freezer so we do everything in Python
we're a python shop and what's nice
about python is this objectoriented kind
of approach and So within our system we
have all these different objects we have
assets which we call tickers we have
portfolios which are made up of tickers
we have accounts we have Brokers any
kind of element that fits into our
system is an object so for each one of
those objects you know how that object
fits into the calculation of whether or
not you decide to trade and for any
instance of an object what we do is we
assign a validation state so we say is
this object valid or not and the way we
determine that is on each one of those
batch processes that we run every 30
minutes
every instance of the objects get run
through this battery of validation test
so right now we're over hundred and
something tests and there are things
like well is there a value missing or is
the value too high or too low relative
to what we should expect or we compare
it to the most recent value and say did
it change more than we would expect and
so you have all these different criteria
that you use to check each one of these
objects to make sure that it's valid if
it fails one of these tests then the
object becomes invalid and we put it
into what we call the freezer which is
basically just a table in our database
and what that means is that that object
cannot contribute to any trading and any
objects which are dependent on it will
also not be able to contribute to any
trading so for instance if you froze a
particular account for some reason an
account got frozen then you wouldn't be
able to trade any of the assets that go
in that account but you'd still be able
to trade the assets let's say you were
trading Apple in two accounts and one
account was frozen then you would stop
trading Apple just in one account you
wouldn't stop trading it in the other
account and then what happens when
something goes into the freezer we get
notified so the system has all these
notification things set up so we get
notified real time that something is
frozen and then that's a signal for us
to go in and look and see if there's a
problem and and either override it or
correct it or whatever it is we need to
do so that's where our human
intervention comes in when things go
into the freezer and you know we had
like one example test that we do do we
test for data gaps we had a big stock
split just two weeks ago with Nvidia
splitting so if you hadn't captured that
corporate action correctly you would
have walked in on Monday and you would
have had a big gap on the open so our
system would capture that on the next
batch and would say hey there's an
unexpected Gap in the price it would put
Nvidia in the freezer and it would stop
trading envidia in every account which
we had a position in Nvidia and it would
notify us hey there's a problem you guys
need to have a look at it and then we
can address it and the really cool thing
about the system is once you have that
it it like creates this protective web
that covers everything because it has
all this inter relationships between all
the objects and how the objects
contribute to the calculations and then
you can also use it for risk management
so we have different limits for

same thing you could have an asset that
Brees some limmit that then gets frozen
